subject: Re: Terminal -ess, American pronunciation conflict?
msgSnippet: ... be ... vowel ... ness) ... by ... set ... #36+#11 ... pronunciation.? ... American ... vowel ... My English Pronouncing Dictionary (by Cambridge
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "steveb_667"
<sbartok1632@e...> wrote:
> I would like to thank everyone who responded to my original inquiry
> about terminal -ier for American pronunciation. I have another
> observation that I would like input on.
>
> On page 20 of the Quikscript manual, it is recommended that for
> terminal -ess (and like endings), that letter combination #28+#11
be
> used. According to the manual, it should be used to avoid using
> #36+#11 again.
>
> My observations for words endings in -ess & the like is that the
vowel
> sound in this particular set of terminals (-ess, -est, -less & -
ness)
> tends to be represented in dictionaries available to me (American)
by
> the "i" sound (letter #26) or the upside-down "e" (letter #36).
> Unfortunately, I do not have access to a British dictionary so I am
> unaware if, again, this rule favors British pronunciation.
>
> Does anyone know a better rationale for using letter #28 for this
set
> of terminals? Is it simply to avoid using letter combination
#36+#11
> over again or does #28+#11 represent the proper British
pronunciation.?
>
> I am leaning towards a proposal of using #26+#11 instead for
American
> pronunciation. This is probably not the optimal solution as some
> dictionaries also use the upside-down "e" (letter #36) for the
vowel
> sound.
>
> Thank you.

My "English Pronouncing Dictionary" (by Cambridge University Press)
also only lists #26 and #36 as acceptable variants in these words. I
believe Read's decision to write those words that way was based
solely on TO's use of the letter 'e', which is why I usually write
#36 in those words.
